close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon::avoid_accept4 (duplicate listed for emphasis on runtime vs compile-time)
MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_* and related error-test macros (MHD_SCKT_EINVAL_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_DISCNN_BEFORE_ACCEPT_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_EAGAIN_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_LOW_RESOURCES_)
explanation: To decide whether any controlling expression in MHD_accept_connection is an invariant (i.e. a compile-time or effectively constant expression) we must know which symbols determine those expressions' values or whether they are compile-time fixed. The items above are required for that reasoning: - USE_ACCEPT4 and _DEBUG: these preprocessor symbols determine how use_accept4 is defined (static const true/false vs computed from daemon->avoid_accept4). If use_accept4 becomes a compile-time constant true/false the if-expressions that test it become invariant. - use_accept4 (local): the actual controlling variable used in the if() conditions; analysis must know whether it is constant or derived from daemon state. - struct MHD_Daemon::avoid_accept4: when _DEBUG && USE_ACCEPT4 use_accept4 is defined from !daemon->avoid_accept4 (runtime) — knowing this field is required to determine if use_accept4 is invariant. - accept4 and accept: these functions are inside the controlling expressions (s = accept4(...) and s = accept(...)); whether those calls are reachable depends on use_accept4 being constant; they also provide side-effects that matter when short-circuiting makes the overall if invariant. - SOCK_CLOEXEC_OR_ZERO, SOCK_NONBLOCK_OR_ZERO, SOCK_NOSIGPIPE_OR_ZERO: these macros set sk_* flags in the accept4 branch; if they are compile-time zero/non-zero they make sk_nonbl/sk_spipe_supprs/sk_cloexec effectively constant immediately after accept4, which can influence later conditionals. - MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS: affects alternate assignments for sk_spipe_supprs in both accept branches (different compile-time behavior on Windows). - MHD_ACCEPT_INHERIT_NONBLOCK: controls whether sk_nonbl is set from daemon->listen_nonblk in the accept() branch (affects whether sk_nonbl becomes a derived constant). - MSG_NOSIGNAL and MHD_socket_nosignal_: presence/absence of these controls whether the SIGPIPE-suppression block is compiled and whether the inner controlling expression (if (! sk_spipe_supprs && ! MHD_socket_nosignal_(s))) exists; that block can become invariant if sk_spipe_supprs is effectively constant. - MHD_INVALID_SOCKET: used in comparisons that form controlling expressions; its value and semantics are needed to reason about invariance and short-circuiting. - struct MHD_Daemon::listen_fd and ::was_quiesced: used in the initial if that may short-circuit the function; these are runtime fields but must be considered to determine if that controlling expression is constant in a given build/context. - struct MHD_Daemon::listen_nonblk and ::listen_is_unix: used to set sk_nonbl and sk_non_ip; their values affect subsequent conditionals. - MHD_socket_get_error_, MHD_SCKT_ERR_IS_* macros and related error-test symbols: these appear in several if() tests after a failed accept; although they usually depend on runtime error code, understanding their semantics is necessary to decide if any of those controlling expressions could be invariant in a given build/platform. - daemon->connections and daemon->at_limit: used in the low-resources branch that changes daemon state; needed to reason about whether the controlling expressions around resource handling are constant. - MHD_socket_close_: used inside a conditional path that may be disabled if MSG_NOSIGNAL or other flags make the controlling expression invariant. In short: the above macros, fields and functions either directly appear in controlling expressions, determine whether other conditional blocks are compiled, or set local booleans that are later tested. Any of those can make an if-condition effectively invariant (compile-time constant or fixed throughout the function call) — hence they are necessary to determine MISRA C Rule compliance for invariant controlling expressions.
